Award.AwardTitle: Failure-Resistant and Self-Healing Communication for Adaptive Mobile System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The need for failure-resistant circuit and system design is becoming critical as mobile devices continue to be constructed with enhanced computing and video processing capabilities using heterogeneous intellectual property blocks such as CPU, memory, sensors, and graphics/image processing units. Furthermore, ever-increasing miniaturization of integrated fabrication processes (e.g., 40 nanometer CMOS or below) is creating challenging problems including higher rates of failure at the device level, reliability degradation, and severe process/voltage/temperature variation, resulting in unpredictable behaviors and temporary or permanent failure of circuits and systems. This project proposes a failure-resistant and variation-tolerant interconnect system that will enhance the reliability of the system at the circuit level. The project will also enhance the self-healing capability of mobile platforms by developing adaptive and automatic fault detection techniques as well as by developing reconfigurable data access capabilities.

Methodologies for developing failure-resistant computing and communication systems are critical for future semiconductor fabrication processes. An innovative failure-resistant and self-healing system could have significant impact on the industry and enhance national competitiveness. The microelectronic industry needs engineers trained in both analog/mixed-signal and radio frequency/microwave integrated circuit and system design. This project will thus contribute to the training of a competitive workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new MBI interface system architecture was developed by Dr Byun and his students. In his words: The failure-resistant and variation tolerant MBI interface system architecture includes a self-healing digital controller and cuircuits such as temperature sensor-based voltage regulator, process detector, digitally controlled impedance calibrator with on-die termination (DT) and off-chip driver (CD), and a multiband signaling interconnect. The self-healing digital controller obtains digital PVT information from a process detector, voltage peak detector with impedence control capabilities and temerature sensor. The voltage regulator with a temperature sensor and trip bound detector can tune the output voltage of the regulator by a tuning digital temperature code from the adaptive feedback loop between a self healing controller and variation sensitive blocks to tolerate server PVT variations. The impedance calibrator adjusts possible impedance mismatches of the MBI transmitter and receiver by using digitally controlled ODT/OCD and digital PVT codes. The error correcting MBI uses multi-band signalling for simultaneous multiple data stream communications by using both baseband and RF bands on shared common transmission line.

The original PI (Dr. Byun) and his students developed a series of circuit elements and building blocks including: novel MBI link, dual sensing mode temperature sensors and multiple PLL components. Multiple graduate students were supported or partially supported on the grant, including two women PhD students. The original PI published over 6 journal papers in IEEE and similar journals. Key building blocks were designed in Cadence and fabricated through MOSIS.
